task.taskName: Model a Voltage Divider Bias CE Transistor

construction: Please construct a model for the voltage-divider biased CE transistor amplifier shown above.  Nodes for the input signal generated have been constructed already.  You need not model the capacitors; just treat them as opens for the DC voltage and shorts for the AC signals. Assume beta is 75, the knee voltage of the BE junction is 0.7v and the resistance of the BE junction is 100 ohms.  Finish the model and view the graph of the output voltage.
incremental: A model for the voltage-divider biased CE transistor amplifier is shown above.   The model ignores the capacitors, just treating them as opens for the DC voltage and shorts for the AC signals.  We assume beta is 100, the knee voltage of the BE junction is 0.7v and the resistance of the BE junction is 100 ohms.
execution: A model for the voltage-divider biased CE transistor amplifier is shown above.   The model ignores the capacitors, just treating them as opens for the DC voltage and shorts for the AC signals.  We assume beta is 100, the knee voltage of the BE junction is 0.7v and the resistance of the BE junction is 100 ohms.
waveform: A model for the voltage-divider biased CE transistor amplifier is shown above.   The model ignores the capacitors, just treating them as opens for the DC voltage and shorts for the AC signals.  We assume beta is 100, the knee voltage of the BE junction is 0.7v and the resistance of the BE junction is 100 ohms.

givenModelNodes.explanation: This is an approximation because it ignores the current going into the base of the transistor. u00a0However, the base current turns out to be so small (6 micro amps) that it can be ignored compared to the 200 micro amps flowing through the voltage divider.

givenModelNodes.name: V at base
givenModelNodes.explanation: Another approximation, because it uses the approximate I through the voltage divider.
